- Explanation of why B is correct. According to the Guidelines for Examination in the EPO, if a European patent application was filed in a non-official language (in this case, Dutch), and Mr Linguist requests unitary effect on 10 October 2024, he must provide a translation of the specification into one of the official languages of the states to which the unitary effect extends. Since the Unitary Patent Framework Agreement (UPCA) is currently signed by 18 countries, these are the relevant jurisdictions here.

- Explanation of why A is incorrect. While the original application was in Dutch, providing a translation into Dutch would not suffice for obtaining unitary patent protection as required by Article 70(4) of the UPCA, which mandates that translations be provided into one of the official languages of the designated states.

- Explanation of why C is incorrect. The 24 countries mentioned are those that have signed the UPCA, but only the 18 countries to which the unitary effect extends would be relevant for this particular request.

- Explanation of why D is incorrect. Providing a translation into Spanish would not comply with the requirement as it must be in one of the official languages of the states extending the unitary effect, and Spanish is not an official language of any such state.
